lines.text: All women are sweet.
I can't understand it. I'm so beautiful, and everybody's always slugging me!
Let the ladies beware, let the music begin. There's many a good tune in an *old* violin.
Many a man has parlayed a box of chocolates into a wife and 4 children.

[opening lines]
Hiya folks, this is me.
And me.
And me.

[as himself]
I'll tell you what these names mean so you can eat your popcorn in peace.
[Arlene Dahl's and Ann Miller's names appear in the opening credits]
Arlene Dahl wanted me to marry Ann Miller, and Ann Miller wanted me to marry Arlene Dahl.

[the movie's title appears on the screen]
This is the title, please tell your friends; we'd like to make a little money with this picture.

[credits continue, showing Leon Ames, Pam Britton, and Richard Rober]
These are the villains, they get paid for being bad; me, I'm different, I'm good for nothing.

[writers' names appear]
We have four writers on this picture; three of them could write, and the other one was my wife's brother.

[other crew members' names appear]
These are the men who control everything; the sound, the photography, the costume, the scenery, the makeup. They tell you what to do,and you do it, they are the bosses. In movies, they call them technicians; in the army, they're called sergeants.

[producer's name appears]
The producer raved about my acting; in fact, they took him away yesterday.
imagination, showmanship, and another job in case the picture's no good.
[opening credits conclude]

[boy enters]
Well, welcome to Cammeron & Son & Son's photographic studios. What can I do for you?
I'd like to buy a camera for $22.50.
Oh... Well, we have a $20 camera, and the price next to that is $25.
I'd like one for $22.50.
Oh... Well, I'll tell you what, we're having a sale today, so I'll give you the 25 dollar camera for $22.50.
Next, I'd like 5 rolls of film at 95 cents a roll.
Five rolls of film... Well, they come in a package of 6, can you use the extra one?
No thanks, just give me 5 rolls of film at 95 cents a roll.
Oh... Well, you seem like a nice little boy. I tell you what, I'll give you all 6 for the price of 5.
Fine, next I'd like a camera case at 3 dollars.
Save your money, you don't need a camera case.
I'd like a 3 dollar camera case.
Yeah... Here's one I'll let you have for 3 dollars.
Thank you, how much does that all come to?
Well, let's find out.
[puts the adding machine on the counter]
[adds up the total]
That comes to 30 dollars and 25 cents.
Are you sure?
Well, this machine's never been wrong yet.
Thank you very much mister, good-bye.
Goodbye - Wait a minute! Hey, don't you want to take your stuff?
No, I just wanted to make sure I had the total right, that was my arithmetic lesson for tomorrow.
[boy leaves the store]
Oh.
[looks at camera with hat on top, mistaking it for a customer]
What can I do for you?
[takes hat off the camera]
Oh.
Oh, welcome to Cammeron & Son & Son's photographic studio, what can I do for you?
My name's Whittle, I'm from the Eagle Collection Agency.
Oh, well there must be some mistake, I don't collect eagles.
My agency's been retained by your creditors to collect the sum of eleven hundred and ninety-seven dollars.
[hands Rusty a bill]
Here's a list of what you owe.
Oh, well I'll have to speak to my father about this.
[reads the invoice]
How could we owe all of that money?
I'm only doing my duty, but if you can't pay this, I'm afraid we'll have to close up your store.
Look mister, all of my savings, all of my father's savings went into opening this store. Now we're liable to take in the $1,197 on this sale alone. Couldn't you give us a little more time, please?
Well, let's say day after tomorrow, but I can't give you one minute more, now that's final.
Thanks.
Good day.
Goodbye.
Say fellas, would you mind coming back tomorrow? I'm having a sale today.
Why don't you write a letter to the newspapers?
Wait a minute! You just fixed this street last week.
Well, you can't expect things to last forever.
No.
Come on.
Hey, wait a minute!

[awakes, sees Lucia]
My camera, where's my camera?
Oh, I'm sorry, but I'm afraid we lost that.
Oh no, why, you should have saved the camera and let me drown. That thing cost $1,200.
Oh I'm sorry, it's all my fault.
All my life, I've been doing things I couldn't afford, but it's the first time I ever got any pleasure out of it.
Achoo!
[camera bulb flashes]

[examines the camera, then picks up the flash bulbs he knocked off the counter]
I wonder if I broke those?

[changes bulb]
Better test them.

[bulb flashes]
That's a good one.

[replaces bulb, it flashes]
That's a good one.

[replaces another bulb, no flash]
Aha, I knew I broke one.
[bulb goes off a second later]

[Rusty hears birds tweeting]
Oh, pardon me, welcome to Cammeron & Son & Son's photographic... Achoo!
[sniffs]
Pardon me, I fell in the water yesterday and caught a little cold. What can I do for you?
I want a camera, anything costing $150.
$150? Right this way.
[walks over to the display counter]
Here's a nice little camera for exactly $150; course, I got another one here for $49, it takes much better pictures.
I'll take the $150 one.
Oh, I'll put it in a nice little box for you.
[customer leaves]
Gee, that makes over $2,000 today.
